Sri Yedukondala Swamy Movie Scenes - Neeladri gives Arun Govil a boon

For people who do not understand telegu, I will try to translate,

One fine day, Godess neeladhri finds Perumal taking nap in neeladhri mountain(one among the seven hills) , she starts admiring the beauty of Perumal, but a quick breeze reveals a bald spot in Perumal's head. She plucks her hair and plants in Perumal's head to make him obsolute beauty.

Perumal wakes up and finds hair in the spot which used to be bald. At the same time he notices blood from neeladhri's head and offers to keep the hair back in her head. But neeladhri refuse the offer and says, in future people will donate their hair to Balaji in order to get rid of sin, Sexual pleasures etc. All those hair that they give reach me only, so do not bother about this.

I learned from my wife that this can be found in various other movies and stories too

I told my wife this is how we lost the scientific culture in the name of religion and told few things that i know of, PFB

In Hindu (atleast in tamil) tradition Mottai/ shaving head/mundan/ kundu etc are done when the baby in 11 months old to clean the head which was in amniotic fluid of mother during the maternity. We need to wait till 11 month in order to let the skull strengthen (softest spot of an infant). Hair will be taken off at least thrice before kid turns 5. (Nowadays i see this stops with the first one)

Adults does this primarily for 2 reasons,

  • To thank god after getting what they wanted( mostly Mundan in Balaji temple is for this.)
  • After loosing somebody in immediate family

Few Information ive gathered,

  • Hair is black in color (for most indians), and this color has attracting quality. It attracts both positive and negative energy. If it is positive energy you will be over joyous if it is negative energy it will lead you to unwanted problems. It directly affects our emotions.
  • Growing hair is never an easy task, weak minds may go lunatic during full moon and no moon days. Even today, people with mental stress related illness are advised to shave off the head irrespective of gender. You don't believe me?? try a beard for 3 months and i bet you will feel the extremes of emotions. After all, beard is not for weaker man :-)
  • Adult grows hair right from the moment they want something. Everybody asks why and he is reminded of what he wants, also every morning seeing his face in mirror reminds him on why he grows hair. So when you are keen on what you want, you will eventually get it. You do not need any one to get it for you. Once he gets it, he thankfully donates his hair which actually ensures he do not go high in emotions which he attracts from his family, friends and neighbors. Even high positive energy is not good if you do not know how to handle it.
  • After loosing a family member, they remove the hair because it attracts the sadness and add fuel to the fire(sadness) they are already in. This was done irrespective of gender in earlier days. There was a wrong understanding that removing hair is only to take off the beauty from women and stopped it in the middle. It is much beyond that.

Coming back to the question, First Mottai/mundan will be done mostly in family gods (Kuladeivam)temple and then it will be done in different temples across the state as they wish. Since Balaji is like kuladeivam for entire Andhra, mundan is done here for almost all Andhra kids. For most of Andhra/Tamilnadu, Tirupathi is far, so once they visit thirupathi they will ensure all the members in the family shave off their heads for whatever they got in last n number of years. Nowadays it has just become a business. It is merely a formality to shave off your head in temple with whatever you got for something you accomplished years ago

In short, our forefathers knew the presence of science even in hair. But modern religions failed to teach hair can give you happiness and sadness, not just externally..Hope you got what you were looking for :-)

Why do people get their head shaved when they visit Tirupati Balaji?

We offer our hair to Balaji to express our love for him.

Love is expressed in two ways: by what we give to our beloved and by what we give up for the sake of our beloved. For example, children can show their love for their parents by studying well and giving them a glowing report card. And they can also show their love by giving up playing before exams so as to focus on studies. Similarly, we can express our devotion for God by giving him precious things like jewels and also by giving up for his sake those things that distract us from him.

One prominent distraction is hair. Though we may say that hair is dirty, we consider it dirty only after it is cut off from the head. As long as it is on the head, we consider it a sign of beauty a part of our hairstyle. We often obsess over it, arranging it, combing it and peeking frequently into a mirror to see if it needs to be re-arranged. Our obsession with hair makes us more infatuated with our body and thereby distracts us from deeper spiritual contemplation.

Thats why the Vedic-wisdom tradition urges us to curb this distraction. In keeping with this guideline, monks shave their heads permanently. The rest of us are recommended to at least shave our head when we go on a pilgrimage. By this, we express our devotion to God by giving up for his sake that which is so dear to us: our beloved hair. For women especially, this is no small sacrifice.

When we shave our head thus at Tirupati, what does Balaji see when the door to his house open? He is not baal-graahi; he is bhaava-graahi (He is eager not for hair, but for devotion). He doesnt see kale baal, saphed baal, dandruff waale baal (He doesnt see black hair, white hair, dandruff-infested hair). He sees the sacrifice, the devotion, the faith that is expressed through that hair.

Even a swan can separate milk from water and accept just the milk. God is the supreme hamsa, the paramahamsa. Why can he not separate the devotion from the hair and accept the devotion? If we think he cant, then thats probably because we cant see beyond the dandruffs to the devotion.

Does this ritual make a business out of our faith? Not at all.

Anyone with even introductory knowledge of Indian traditions knows that the tradition of offering hair at a pilgrimage long predates the modern business of mass-producing wigs. Due to the popularity of wigs in todays world, discarded human hair is in great demand. If the hair that for centuries was just being brushed away as waste can be easily recycled to gain money for opening schools,hospitals and orphanages, then whats wrong with that? As it is, many modern people are going to spend money on wigs. Why not let that money come to God and through him go to the needy? It is not that the ritual of shaving the hair was createdto make money by selling hair. Such a notion arises from ones ignorance of history. So the practice of cutting hair is primarily meant to give us an opportunity for expressing our devotion to God by sacrificing something dear for his sake. The money that is made out of the hair is just an incidental byproduct.

ye shraddha ka dhanda nahi hai, ye waste ka dhanda hai. akalmandi ki baat hai. (This does not make a business out of our faith. It makes a business out of waste matter. It is an intelligent thing.)

Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanam (TTD) as per their policy, they dont give back the offered hair. Incase, if you want to donate it to the cancer patients, it is not necessary to shave your head. You can donate a minimum of 12 inches of your hair. After then, you can tonsure your remaining hair at Tirumala.

it is a way to have a self control and purify your mind and souls.

That's the reason why a sanyasi also shaves his head regularly, to keep away attachment and attain spiritual realisation.

Is Hundi donation confidential at Tirupati Balaji Temple in Andra Pradesh?

If Im not wrong, I think you are asking about the donations that TTD receives in hundi. The answer is NO. Not at all. Once the Hundi gets filled up, then it will be moved to a place called Parakamani. During this they will take a signature of proof from two devotees who are standing in that area and then it will be moved to Parakamani.

Everyday the TTD parakamani employees will leave to their house after counting it completely. No rupee will be left or added to the next day donations. Once the counting is done, they will list down all the money received from donations and their expenditure i

If Im not wrong, I think you are asking about the donations that TTD receives in hundi. The answer is NO. Not at all. Once the Hundi gets filled up, then it will be moved to a place called Parakamani. During this they will take a signature of proof from two devotees who are standing in that area and then it will be moved to Parakamani.

Everyday the TTD parakamani employees will leave to their house after counting it completely. No rupee will be left or added to the next day donations. Once the counting is done, they will list down all the money received from donations and their expenditure in purchase of daily needs, goods and many more things.

In the next day after tomala seva, this list will be read in front of Sri Venkateswara Swami. They will also includes the employee salary and money which is in TTDs account and the amount of gold which came under donations. And then immediately the last day donations are transferred to the TTDs account. All this process goes under the secured zone of Sri Venkateswara Swami.

No single rupee is confidential here.

Does anybody know about Tirupati Balaji? What is the official dress, darshan or room rent cost?

There are three ways of dharshanam in tirumala balaji temple. They are FREE DHARSHANAM, PEDESTRIANS ENTRY and SPECIAL ENTRY.

  1. FREE DHARSHANAM - Anyone can go through this section for dharshan. No Fee and No dress code. But the dharshanam time depends on the crowd. The time duration for dharshan in this section is large when compared to pedestrian section and special entry section.
  2. PEDESTRIAN ENTRY - Those who came By walk to tirumala from tirupati through Steps are Eligible to go through this section for dharshan. And here also No fee and No dress code. The time duration in this section for dharshan is Moderate.

SPECIAL ENTRY - You Can book tickets online for dharshanam. The official website is ttdsevaonline.com it will cost around 350/- rs per head for Dharshan and Laddus. In this section you have to wear Traditional dress like dhothi - pyjama For men and sary for women. When compared to the previous dharshans, the time duration for dharshan in this section is less. The dharshan timings may vary Based on the number of piligrims on that particular date.

Accommodation - You can book rooms through the official site I've already mentioned or you can book them directly in tirumala.

But the chances of getting a room by direct approach solely depends on the crowd.

And while visiting tirumala Balaji, please adjust with the accommodation facilities and other things apart from dharshanam. If the crowd is too high, we can't expect such facilities over there.

There is no such rule imposed ever in the history of Tirumula.. However it became a regular thing from the starting of the days the temple has been established..

It became more famous when niluvudopidi started which means giving all the belongings of us to the eternal Lord Venkateswara swamy and seeking the blessings..

Giving our hair is an indication to not have unseperable bond with any material things and not to have ego..

According to puranas, when srinivasa came to earth to search for his beloved wife padmavathi devi(lakshmi devi) had to hide in an ant's house(cheemala putta in telugu not sure what is called in english) he suffered an injury by govulakapari (who looks after cows) while one the cows is automatically pouring milk in that ant's house..

Becuase of that injury he lost a portion of his hair and a woman (neelambiri or something i dont remeber correctly) out of pity gave her own hair by cutting a portion..

For a woman cutting hair is a big thing in ancient days. For her kindness Srinivasudu gave her a boon saying all my devotees who ever donate their hair will belong to you.

No.

He visited the earth in search of Goddess Lakshmi and was meditating around Nallamala forests and the present Tirupati, where he even married Princess Padmavati Devi.

Lord Karthikeya is the son of Lord Shiva and Parvati and brother of Lord Ganesha.

Why and for what are people shaving their hair only at Tirupati temples?

The story is mentioned below:

When Lord Balaji was hit on his head by a shepherd, a small portion of his scalp became bald. This was noticed by Neela Devi, a Gandharva princess. She felt "such an attractive face should not have a flaw". Immediately, she cut a portion of her hair and, with her magical power, implanted it on his scalp. Lord Balaji noticed her sacrifice. As hair is a beautiful asset of the female form, he promised her that all his devotees who come to his abode would offer their hair to him, and she would be the recipient of all the hair received. Hence, it is believed that hair offered by the devotees is accepted by Neela Devi. The hill, Neeladri, one of the seven hills, is named after her.


Source:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tirumala_Venkateswara_Temple#Hair_tonsuring

Why do people donate hair at Tirupati Balaji?

There is hardly any temple in India where there is the tradition of devotees donating their hair, but this tradition of offering hair in Tirupati Balaji temple has been going on for years, which is called Mokku. It would be surprising to know, but according to one data, 20 thousand people donate their hair every year.

The tradition of donating hair in Tirupati Balaji is quite old. According to Hindu belief, the reason behind giving this donation is said to be that Lord Venkateswara repays the loan taken from Kubera. It is believed that the price of hair we give, Lord Venkateswara, gives you t

There is hardly any temple in India where there is the tradition of devotees donating their hair, but this tradition of offering hair in Tirupati Balaji temple has been going on for years, which is called Mokku. It would be surprising to know, but according to one data, 20 thousand people donate their hair every year.

The tradition of donating hair in Tirupati Balaji is quite old. According to Hindu belief, the reason behind giving this donation is said to be that Lord Venkateswara repays the loan taken from Kubera. It is believed that the price of hair we give, Lord Venkateswara, gives you ten times more than that. The good thing is that devotees here donate hair of their own free will.

Six hundred barbers have been recruited here to carry out this task with full tradition. These donated hair are sold abroad at good prices. Since the quality of Indian hair is very good, it is well received abroad.

What is the significance behind people offering their hair to God?

Hair is the ornamental part of human body. While people offer in most temples such as Tirupathi Balaji Narasimha temples and many others.

The legend behing Tirumala is that when Lord Balaji or Venkatesha was hit by a cowherd on his head, Lords Mother Vakulamba tore her hairs and pressed on the wound to stop Lords bleeding. Hence people offer their hair in Tirumala.

Another reason vedic scholars attribute is hair gives glamour and ego to humans to flaunt. We offer our hair as symbol of sacrifice of our ego and glamour at the feet of the Lord or Goddess.

When all people have tonsured their heads, there is no ego no heirarchy, all are equal among us.

Therefore people tonsure their heads in offering to The God or Goddess of temple they visit.

Are married Indian women allowed to donate hair to the Tirupati Balaji temple after their wishes are fulfilled?

It depends on the caste/communities. The Brahmins, the Arya Vaishyas, and some other such castes do not shave their heads at any cost, married or unmarried. That is because tonsuring the head was the inauspicious sign of widowhood. Now even that practice is gone. So no woman from these Brahmins, Arya Vaishya etc., will donate hair. In Brahmins even men wont shave their head, since it is done only when someone dies in the family.

There are several other communities whose women shave their heads at several temples including Tirupati. These people are the majorities. They dont consider it is inauspicious.

The temple/temple authorities will allow any man or women to donate their hairs for whatever reason it is, regardless of their marriage status or caste/community. The temple will not discriminate between devotees in this matter and they will never question anybody.

Therefore is just the question of whether the community you belong to allows tonsuring the head for a married woman or not. Better inquire with the elders of your family or community as to what your traditional practices have been. in this matter
